>   I see TruTV also removed where it was stated Mr. Moon is the "sole"
> possesor of the Box. But still, it disses the person who brought this
> technology to the public, and that is Mr. Sumption. Thanks to thoses
> that contacted the network to set the record straight but the Edison
> connection is wishful thinking, and a distortion of statements made
> in the 1920's in Forbes followed by American Scientific magazine led
> to the assumption such a device was being worked on. He is the single
> quote by Edison that has resulted in a bit of history being
> twisted: "if we can evolve an instrument so delicate as to be
> affected by our personality as it survives in the next life, such an
> instrument, when made available, ought to record something."

> > Hi, Rick.

> > Back in the day when I was working on my Ph.D. thesis, which
> involved some technical stuff about the history of the development of
> multitrack recording, and the effects of electronic mediation on
> vocal music performance, I came across a reference to Edison. I
> apologize, but I have long since lost the original citation, so I
> can't offer it to you.
> >
> > What I remember from my research at the time was that Edison did
> indeed believe that the voices of spirits could be recorded, and in
> fact his work on what turned out to be the phonograph (capturing
> voices on wax cylinders, later on flat platters, later on what we
> call records) was intended to eventually lead to being able to record
> spirit voices. Apparently he got as far as figuring out how to record
> incarnate human voices <g>, but stopped before he got any spirit
> voices. I seem to dimly remember some comment that he thought his
> technology needed to be further developed, but he didn't pursue it,
> at least not in any way that has ever been publicly disclosed.
> >
> > Hope this helps, though the citation is lacking!
> >
> > Best,
> >
> > Leslie

> >like to know the real story.
